projects.title: matt-daemon
projects.description: C++11 implementation of a true UNIX daemon: background execution with root privileges, listening on port 4242, and concurrent management limited to three clients. Every action, message, or signal is logged with a timestamp in /var/log/matt_daemon/, ensuring traceability and system robustness.
projects.detail: Introductory project to daemonized processes on Linux. The MattDaemon program operates as a standalone network service: secure initialization (fork, setsid, flock), persistent listening socket, clean signal handling, and lock via /var/lock/matt_daemon.lock. Client exchanges are recorded, and the quit command triggers controlled shutdown. The architecture is based on modular classes (file management, Tintin_reporter logger, server, daemonizer) tested on Debian via Docker with persistent volumes for logs.

projects.title: little-penguin-1
projects.description: Series of Linux kernel development exercises: compile and boot Linus’ kernel, write/port modules, automate via udev, expose interfaces (misc, debugfs), and produce reproducible proofs.
projects.detail: Hands-on kernel development journey: compilation/boot of kernels (mainline & linux-next), writing simple modules and drivers, userspace integration (udev, procfs, debugfs, misc). Objectives: master the kernel toolchain and workflow (config, build, patch), strictly apply the Linux Kernel Coding Style, and produce reproducible proofs (logs, patches). Project focused on low-level mechanisms and kernel↔userspace interfaces, without abstraction layers.

projects.title: ft_linux
projects.description: Recreate a Linux distribution from scratch: compile and install a kernel, prepare partitions, userspace, and a bootable system.
projects.detail: Prepare a build environment, create partitions (/boot, /, swap), compile a toolchain and build a minimal system. Compile and install a Linux kernel (version ≥ 4.0), install sources, configure udev, install a bootloader, set up an init (SysV or systemd), and ensure the machine boots cleanly. All subject requirements strictly followed (partitions, names, paths, udev present, hostname). The work is reproducible on VM, with a Makefile/scripts and build documentation.

projects.title: ft_ssl_md5
projects.description: Implementation in C of MD5 and SHA-256 hashing algorithms: read from files or stdin, output formatting compatible with OpenSSL.
projects.detail: Create a ft_ssl program able to hash with MD5 and SHA-256 on files or standard input. Output formats strictly respected (echo/print style, flags -p/-q/-r/-s), handle padding, block splitting, endianness, and produce results identical to OpenSSL/sha256sum/md5sum. Robust code (error handling, missing files), optimized and covered by comparative unit tests against standard tools. The implementation demonstrates understanding of bitwise operations, standard constants, and the structure of hashing algorithms.

projects.title: ft_malcolm
projects.description: Minimal implementation of ARP spoofing in C: listens for a broadcast ARP request from the target for the source IP, sends a single forged ARP Reply. Project made to understand Layer 2/Ethernet, ARP (RFC 826), and basic Man In The Middle attack.
projects.detail: Introductory Cybersecurity project. The program takes 4 required arguments in this order: source IP, source MAC, target IP, target MAC. It specifically waits for a broadcast ARP request from the target asking for the source IP, then crafts and sends a single ARP Reply (Ethernet+ARP) to the target before exiting cleanly. The program handles errors, signals, and follows low-level programming constraints. Implementation: automatic interface selection from source IP, strict validation of received frame, construction of a packed reply (sha/spa/tha/tpa), targeted sending; readable logs, verbose mode with hex dump, Makefile, and Docker lab (attacker/victim + tcpdump/wireshark) for the demo.

projects.title: ft_linear_regression
projects.description: Implementation of linear regression (gradient descent) to estimate car price based on mileage, with training and prediction programs, visualizations, and metrics.
projects.detail: Introductory machine learning project to train a simple linear regression model on a km/price dataset and predict a price from a given mileage. The 42 subject requires two separate programs (train & predict), use of gradient descent, and forbids libraries that do 'all the work', with bonuses like plotting data/model line and precision calculation. Implementation: robust CSV parsing with validations (immutable dataset, handling empty/error lines), min-max feature normalization, gradient descent training with periodic logs, convergence tolerance and safeguards against divergence, saving parameters in a JSON (`theta0`, `theta1`, `x_min`, `x_max`), and interactive CLI predictor. An evaluation module computes MAE/RMSE/MSE/R² and an optional bonus displays a Matplotlib graph (points, model line, validity zone, prediction annotation).

projects.title: Swifty-Proteins
projects.description: iOS/macOS app in SwiftUI to visualize 3D proteins from the Protein Data Bank, with biometric authentication.
projects.detail: Swifty-Proteins is an advanced mobile project from 42 school introducing 3D rendering and modern mobile frameworks. The app consumes the PDB (Protein Data Bank) to display molecules and ligands in 3D with SceneKit. It includes biometric authentication (TouchID/FaceID), user management (create/login), a ligand list with search engine, interactive 3D viewer (zoom, rotate, atom info tooltip, CPK coloring, Ball-and-Stick representation), and social sharing features. Bonuses allow adding other visualization styles or alternative models. The project combines structural biology and native mobile development for an interactive and educational experience.

projects.title: Matcha
projects.description: Creation of a complete dating site, with profiles, matching, real-time chat and notifications, end-to-end security.
projects.detail: Matcha is a web project from 42 school to develop a modern and secure dating app. Users can register, log in, complete their profile (gender, preferences, bio, interests with tags, photos), and see who viewed or 'liked' their profile. The app integrates a matching engine based on geolocation, common interests, and a 'fame rating'. It includes advanced search by criteria (age, location, tags), profile viewing with visit history, likes/matches management, and real-time chat with instant notifications (likes, views, messages). Bonuses include social login (Omniauth), photo import, interactive maps, and even scheduled dates. Everything is fully secured (hashed passwords, form validation, protection against SQL injection and XSS).

projects.title: Tokenizer
projects.description: Web3 project to create and deploy a custom BEP-20 token on the BNB blockchain with documentation and tests.
projects.detail: Tokenizer is a blockchain project from 42 school, in partnership with BNB Chain. The goal is to design and deploy a custom digital token (must contain '42' in its name) on a public compatible blockchain, here BNB Smart Chain. The project includes smart contract development (ERC-20 or BEP-20 standard), writing a README detailing technical choices, deployment on testnet, and publishing the token on an explorer (BscScan, Blockscan). The repo architecture includes a `code` folder for contracts, a `deployment` folder for deployment scripts, and a `documentation` folder for explanations and whitepaper. Security and privilege management (ownership, pause, burn, mint as chosen) are essential. As a bonus, integrating a multisignature system can enhance transaction security. The project covers Solidity, development tools (Hardhat, Truffle, Remix), and the Web3 ecosystem.

projects.title: Inception of Things
projects.description: Introductory project to Kubernetes with Vagrant, K3s, K3d and GitOps (Argo CD), developed at 42 school.
projects.detail: This project aims to get familiar with Kubernetes from a developer's perspective. Start by creating one or more virtual machines with Vagrant (part 1). Next, deploy a K3s cluster and run several apps with an Ingress (part 2). The last step involves K3d with Argo CD to set up CI/CD directly from a GitHub repo (part 3). An optional bonus is integrating GitLab + CI/CD with Argo CD for automatic app synchronization on the cluster.

projects.title: Swifty-Companion
projects.description: iOS app in SwiftUI using the 42 API to display student information.
projects.detail: Swifty-Companion is a mobile project at 42 school. It's an iOS app in SwiftUI that consumes the official 42 API via OAuth2 (Intranet) to dynamically display user data. The app includes a home view with a search field (42 login), a student profile view (login, level, location in school, coalition, completed projects, skills, profile photo), a reactive architecture for multiple screen sizes, and robust error handling (login not found, API unavailable, network/auth issues). Bonuses like OAuth2 token refresh on expiration and auto-reconnect are possible if the mandatory part is perfect. All follows security best practices, including `.env` ignored for API keys.

projects.title: BibleFlow
projects.description: Swift mobile app for offline Bible reading, multilingual, for iOS and macOS.
projects.detail: BibleFlow is a Swift mobile app designed to offer a complete Bible reading experience without internet connection. It supports multiple languages for biblical texts, an adaptive interface for iOS and macOS, and smooth navigation between books, chapters, and verses. The app focuses on accessibility and offline performance. Currently in development, it includes management of different translations, local storage of Bible versions, and a modern responsive UI based on SwiftUI (or UIKit), with future features like search, favorites, annotations, or data sync between devices.

projects.title: BTCpay Server – Crypto Payments
projects.description: Deployment of a self-hosted BTCpay server to accept cryptocurrency payments (BTC, XMR, LTC, DOGE, DASH) in a sovereign, secure, and intermediary-free way.
projects.detail: Setup of BTCpay Server on an on-prem Debian server via Docker, with a secure reverse proxy and protected remote access. Wallet configuration for multiple cryptocurrencies (Bitcoin, Monero, Litecoin, Dogecoin, Dash), dynamic invoice generation, integration of a full node for each, and local key management without third parties. This project strengthens financial autonomy and applies advanced concepts of decentralization, security, and digital sovereignty. Special attention is paid to infrastructure resilience, network security, and user experience for both merchant and client.

projects.title: Personal HomeLab
projects.description: Deployment of a complete HomeLab on Debian server with AI, DevOps, virtualization and security via private VPN.
projects.detail: Installation and configuration of a Debian server on a recycled physical machine to host a personal HomeLab via CasaOS. Setup of Tailscale for secure and encrypted remote access. Deployment and management of advanced services via Docker: local AI chatbot (Ollama CPU + Open WebUI), development environment (VSCode Server), productivity tools (Ghostfolio, Wallos, LibreTranslate, Stirling PDF, ConvertX, IT Tools), media player (Navidrome), remote desktop (Webtop), and a custom YouTube Downloader. Centralized logs via Dozzle. All services are containerized, isolated, and accessible only via VPN. This project implements best practices in system administration, network security, virtualization, and DevOps, using modern self-hosting tools.

projects.title: Automated Trading Bot
projects.description: Development of a crypto trading bot using Freqtrade, a custom DCA strategy, and a UI accessible via Cloudflare Tunnel.
projects.detail: Creation of an automated trading bot based on Freqtrade, integrating an advanced DCA (Dollar-Cost Averaging) strategy optimized for a minimum annual return of 15%. The bot monitors market trends and applies smart buy/sell orders based on technical indicators. Performance validated by backtests over several years: 2022 (15.05%), 2023 (17.83%), and 2024 (16.42%). The app is deployed on an on-prem Linux server, ensuring full control over infrastructure. Docker virtualization ensures optimal service isolation and easy updates/scalability. A UI via Freqtrade UI allows real-time monitoring of open positions, performance, and transaction history. A Cloudflare tunnel secures remote access to the interface and ensures smooth bot management without direct Internet exposure.

projects.title: Portfolio Website
projects.description: Creation of an interactive portfolio to showcase my work.
projects.detail: Development of an interactive website to present my professional and personal projects. The site is hosted on Azure Static Web Apps for optimal performance and simplified deployment management. The domain name is managed by Infomaniak. A custom routing service in pure JavaScript is used for smooth navigation between site sections and to ensure Single Page Application principles. The design is minimalist and modern thanks to picoCSS.

projects.title: Cloud-1
projects.description: Implementation of a complete WordPress environment with Docker Compose on Azure.
projects.detail: This project consists of creating a complete WordPress environment using Docker containers for WordPress, MariaDB, phpMyAdmin, and Nginx, deployed on an Azure VM. Containers are orchestrated with Docker Compose and automated via Ansible for deployment and configuration. The environment uses SSL certificates to secure connections and ensures data persistence for MariaDB and WordPress.

projects.title: Libft
projects.description: Recreate the main functions of the C standard library.
projects.detail: Development of a personal library by recreating several essential functions of the C standard library, focusing on best practices and efficient memory management.

projects.title: Get Next Line
projects.description: Read a line from a file efficiently.
projects.detail: Creation of a function able to read line by line from a file or standard input, using buffers to optimize performance.

projects.title: Ft_printf
projects.description: Reproduce the printf function from the C standard library.
projects.detail: Development of a custom version of the printf function, supporting multiple formats and specifications, while efficiently managing memory.

projects.title: Born2BeRoot
projects.description: Configure a secure virtual machine.
projects.detail: Installation and configuration of a secure virtual machine based on Debian. This project covers several essential aspects of system management, including downloading and installing the VM, initial setup, SSH connection, and setting up strict security policies. Concepts include virtualization with VirtualBox, user and permission management, installation and configuration of essential services like SSH and UFW, and setting up robust password policies and security logs.

projects.title: Push_Swap
projects.description: Implement a sorting algorithm with a limited number of operations.
projects.detail: The push_swap project consists of developing a C program that takes a list of integers as command-line arguments and outputs a sequence of operations to optimally sort these integers. The program uses two stacks, 'a' and 'b', and a limited set of stack manipulation operations to sort the integers. Allowed operations include swaps, rotations, and pushes between stacks. The goal is to minimize the total number of operations performed to sort the stack.

projects.title: Minitalk
projects.description: Creation of a client-server app to exchange messages via Unix signals.
projects.detail: Development of a simple client-server communication system using Unix signals as the transmission medium. The client sends a message to the server, which receives and displays it. The client converts each character of the message into a sequence of bits and sends them to the server using SIGUSR1 and SIGUSR2 signals. The server reconstructs the message from the received bits and displays it. The server confirms receipt of each message by sending a signal to the client. The project also includes bonus features such as Unicode character support.

projects.title: So_Long
projects.description: Development of a 2D game in C based on a graphics library.
projects.detail: Welcome to So_Long, a 2D game project developed in C as part of a programming learning program. This project focuses on creating a simple game using the MinilibX graphics library. The goal is to build a game where a player moves through a map, collects objects, avoids obstacles, and reaches the exit. The game involves user input handling, graphics rendering, and management of game elements such as player, objects, obstacles, and exit. The project includes event handling, animations, and interactions with the environment.

projects.title: Philosophers
projects.description: Simulation of a classic multithreading algorithm problem.
projects.detail: This program implements the simulation of the classic dining philosophers problem using threads and mutexes in C. The simulation involves philosophers alternating between eating, thinking, and sleeping. They use forks to eat and put them back on the table when done. Philosophers must never starve, and the simulation stops when a philosopher dies of starvation. The program must be written without global variables and should take arguments such as the number of philosophers, time limits for eating, sleeping, and dying, and an optional argument for the number of meals each philosopher must take before the simulation ends. The program must also log events and ensure philosophers avoid starvation. The program can be implemented with threads and mutexes or processes and semaphores (in my case, threads & mutexes).

projects.title: Minishell
projects.description: Creation of a minimalist shell inspired by Bash.
projects.detail: In our 'Minishell' project at 42 school, we develop a simplified shell program. This challenge is crucial for understanding processes and file descriptors. Our goal is to create a minimalist version of bash, immersing ourselves in the nuances of shell programming. We focus on fundamental aspects such as command input handling, file directory manipulation, environment variable interpretation, and implementing essential features like signal handling and command execution. This project is an important step toward a deep understanding of system programming, offering practical experience with key concepts used in Unix/Linux shell environments.

projects.title: Cub3D
projects.description: Development of a 3D game inspired by Wolfenstein 3D with ray-casting.
projects.detail: This project consists of creating a first-person 3D game using ray-casting to render a maze. The game is developed with the MiniLibX graphics library and includes features such as player movement, shooting, and texture management.

projects.title: NetPractice
projects.description: Learning the fundamental concepts of networking.
projects.detail: The NetPractice project is an exciting challenge from 42 school aimed at deepening and practicing my networking skills. This project is a unique opportunity to dive into the complex and fascinating world of networks, learning to manipulate, configure, and troubleshoot in real and simulated network environments. Objectives include understanding networking fundamentals, including OSI and TCP/IP models, mastering configuration and management of network devices such as switches and routers, and applying troubleshooting techniques to identify and resolve network issues.

projects.title: C++ Piscine (part.1)
projects.description: Introduction to object-oriented programming in C++.
projects.detail: Discovering the basics of object-oriented programming with C++. Focus on classes, objects, and modularity. Understanding ad-hoc polymorphism, overloads, and orthodox canonical classes in C++. Learning memory allocation, references, member pointers, and switch usage in C++. Exploring C++ specifics compared to C, with a dive into object-oriented programming. Studying subtype polymorphism, abstract classes, and interfaces in C++. Understanding inheritance in C++ and its implications for robust and modular software design.

projects.title: C++ Piscine (part.2)
projects.description: Deepening advanced C++ concepts.
projects.detail: Deepening advanced C++ features such as templates, different types of casts, use of standard containers (STL), 'template containers', iterators and 'algorithms', as well as exception handling with Try/Catch blocks. The project also includes implementing generic programming concepts, handling smart pointers, and optimizing performance through advanced memory management techniques.

projects.title: Inception
projects.description: Deployment of a complex and secure web infrastructure with Docker.
projects.detail: As part of our curriculum at 42 school, we tackle the project called 'Inception'. This ambitious project is part of a process to deepen and apply knowledge in virtualization and container management. Our goal is to deploy a complex and secure infrastructure, fully configured with Docker and orchestrated by docker-compose, all in a dedicated virtual machine. The architecture includes several key components: a Docker container with NGINX, a container dedicated to WordPress + php-fpm, a container for MariaDB, two separate volumes for the database and website files, and a specific Docker network for inter-container communication. Containers must be built from custom Dockerfiles, without using prebuilt Docker images or services like DockerHub.

projects.title: Webserv
projects.description: Implementation of a web server in C++ following the HTTP protocol.
projects.detail: The Webserv project at 42 school consists of implementing a web server in C++ to the C++98 standard. This server must be able to serve static files and handle CGI requests. It must also handle multiple simultaneous connections, large files asynchronously and non-blocking. Additionally, the server must support HTTP GET, POST, and DELETE methods, as well as CGI requests for GET and POST. It must handle errors and return appropriate HTTP status codes. The server must also handle requests with large headers and bodies, with a limit defined in the config file. The reference behavior for this project is Nginx.

projects.title: Ft_Transcendence
projects.description: Development of a complete web app for an online multiplayer game.
projects.detail: Creation of a web platform for a real-time multiplayer game, including WebSocket. The project includes user management, local and remote multiplayer support, a tournament system, statistics tables, and advanced security measures such as password hashing and protection against XSS/SQL Injection attacks. The backend is managed by a custom Web module, the database is integrated, and the frontend uses JavaScript with a modern toolkit. The app is a SPA compatible with Chrome, with no console errors, and launches with a single command.

projects.title: Shell Modules
projects.description: Introduction to shell scripts and Unix command management.
projects.detail: This project explores the basics of shell scripting, essential Unix commands, and their use in a Linux environment. The goal is to learn to automate common tasks.

projects.title: C Modules
projects.description: First basics of C language, logic and simple algorithms.
projects.detail: Learning the basics of C language, including data structures, loops, and functions. Projects also focus on algorithmic logic and compilation tools.

projects.title: Rushes
projects.description: Intensive team challenges to solve complex problems.
projects.detail: Collaborative work on complex challenges with short deadlines, aiming to improve problem-solving skills and team communication.
